reviewText:
As a huge Spider-Man fan (and a comic book fan in general) it's hard to give this games a thumbs down, yet it's hard from a gamer's perspective to give it a thumbs up. The Amazing Spider-Man 2 can be enjoyable for Spider-Man fans, but the average gamer will definately find a ton of frustrations in an otherwise enjoyable game.

THE PROS:
· The story is pretty good, with some interresting villains like the King Pin and Kraven the Hunter.
· Refferences to both the movies and the general Spider-Man lore.
· Completing Hide-Outs will grant you with a new Spidey suit.
· Collectibles offer a lot for Spider-Man fans. You can view your collectibles in Stan Lee's comic book store!
· Spider-Man's web will (most of the time) realistically stick to buildings.
· Spidey has some sweet lookin' moves in both his swinging and comat.

THE CONS:
· Even though the camera has been greatly improved over the original Amazing Spider-Man game, the combat feels a bit unresponsive and too stiff. It's safe to say they're trying to copy the Batman Arkham-series' combat, but it often feels like you're punching thin air because the henchmen you're beating up react unrealistically to Spider-Man's punches and kicks.
· A terrible presentation. The menus looks dull and boring, like they were back on the days of the Playstation One.
· I wouldn't call these Side Missions actual side missions, because you're sort of forced to do them. If you don't do them, they people will start to see Spider-Man as a mennace in stead of a hero. This wouldn't be a huge deal if the side missions were fun, buy they're largely boring and downright repetetive. You don't get a good enough chance to explore the city when uninterresting side missions pop up randomly across the map for a limited time.
· Visiting Aunt May's house to change costumes requires you to hop on a train that's only on some points of the map. Sure it makes sense, but changing costumes on the fly would be a lot easier. You can easily lose a couple of minutes to find the train, web onto it, get your costume off and get in your Peter Parker clothes, go upstairs, pick a suit, go back outside just to find out it's not really the costume you really want to wear. Cosumes grant a slight bonus (which is very welcome) but in order to avoid going through this time consuming and boring process of switching suits will probably just leave you playing with one specific costume.

THE VISUALS:
· The overal detail in the world is very good... if it was 2007. Textures on Spidey's suit look bad and blocky, faces look like they're made out of wet clay, the camera will sometimes clip through an object like a wall in the middle of a cutscene. It's basically a pretty bugged game with very few pretty skyline sights, but they mostly look like a downgrade from the original.

FINAL VERDICT:
· If you're a big Spider-Man fan, probably pick this up on sale to scratch that itch for a decent Spider-Man game. It feels like a rushed product that is a general downgrade from the original with only very few improvements that quickly fade away in the game's frustrating issues. 6/10

reviewText:
This game gave me the strong impression that the developers intended to make the money piggy backing off of the film release and not make a polished game.  I was disappointed because Beenox has made very good Spider-Man titles previous to this one.

There are many issues, only magnified by the fact that I found Amazing Spider-Man 1 to be such a good game.  There are no improvements to the combat system (I found it to be buggier and less satisfying than the original game). Web-swinging took some getting used to, which only made the fact that the game required you to travel long distances in a short amount of time more obvious and frustrating.  The mechanic of requiring random events took all of the fun out of saving citizens, and the lack of any impact other than making your life harder made it unsatisfying.  Some of the events were similar to older games, and the fact that it made me irritated rather than nostalgic showed me that there was little thought to making completing them fun.

The story of Amazing Spider-Man 1 game was not during the film and allowed for the introduction of some iconic villains while building on the plot, while making some epic boss battles with huge and difficult adversaries.  Amazing Spider-Man 2 lazily makes the game's plot during the movie, forcing lackluster introductions and battles with very good villains, creating large holes in the movie plot, and making generic enemies not on par with the varied and satisfying plot and enemies of Amazing Spider-Man 1.

A positive aspect of the game was that it does have a lot of nods to fans, the unlockable suits were satisfying, but they made the most desirable premium DLC, which removes the positive in my opinion.  I liked being rewarded by being able to read comics by finding the collectables scattered throughout the world, and there was some insinuation of what was to come.  Ultimately, this game made me question pre-ordering a Spider-Man game again.

reviewText:
Amazingly short is what The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is. The main story can be finished in roughly 3-4 hours, but if you do all of the monotonous sidequests I guess you can add 5-10 hours to that number. Add to that that it's an extremely poorly optimized port, with constant framerate drops and the fact that it follows an entirely different story than the movie and bam; we have a winner for yet another movie cash-in game, even if it isn't identical. They just had to release this close to the movie.

If only they worked on this for 6 months longer this could've been semi-great. The first Amazing Spider-Man wasn't without its problems, but at least it was somewhat polished, and definitely longer.

Now, the graphics, on the other hand, are pretty good, even if it could've used more detail on street level (swinging through these streets is really cool, though). The game in general has a colorful look.
And it's a real shame that they didn't use the movie actors for the voices. Things felt a bit forced I thought, and the one-liners were repeated way too often (why the heck is it called an one-liner if it's repeated every couple of minutes ?). A missed opportunity.

Play this if you're a big Spider-Man fan, or if you've played all of the other titles before. Or just wait for a sale if you really, really want to play it.

The first one, with it's crashes and shortcomings, its still far better than the sequel.

That is not to say that TASM2 is a bad game, it is a poorly executed mediocre one that falls short on everything it could have been.

The web swinging is tedious, tiring and slow.

The random events are on a timer even if you haven't activated them, so every random event on the map will expire after a while, guess what happens if they expire? You descend into menace status because you did nothing to prevent it.

More menace bars = More security forces chasing you.

The photo ops from the first game, which shed insight and references to the Spider-man universe now instead gives you recorded dialogue from a couple of in-game characters.

The storyline itself is rushed and it feels that the game rushes to the finish line by throwing one boss after the other.

Not everything is bad though, some positive points would be the wider selection of outfits, that they augment different stats/abilities, and that they are easier to acquire.

All in all a mediocre tie-in game to afraid to break from its film's constraints to achieve finality.

P.S. it would have been slightly more tolerable if it wasn't for those stupid after-action reports after every menace/hero mission

A relatively short period into the game and you're forced to repeat the same 9 crime stopping missions in tiny areas preceded and followed by quickly tiresome cutscenes as often as possible, and it only increases in frequency as the game goes on. Yeah.  Overall the only feeling this game leaves me with is that it is entirely too tedious to actually enjoy in any capacity once it gets going.

For movie spoilers, I'm almost certain there are none, but I think you do learn a bit about how Harry Osborne becomes the green goblin, other than that it seems basically spoiler free.

-Gameplay-
The web swinging seemed to work really well, although sometimes when going over certain areas like parks and such, you will latch onto nothing. reviewText:
With The Amazing Spider-Man 2 movie out, another Spider-Man game comes along with it. The first The Amazing Spider-Man game was served as an epilogue to the main film. The Amazing Spider-Man 2 video game takes a different approach as it has a unique storyline of its own that has little sprinkles from the actual movie.
Amazing Spider-Man 2 the game starts with you as Peter Parker on the night his uncle, Ben Parker is shot and killed. The game then flashes forward somewhere in time between the first and second films, with Peter still looking for the thief who killed his uncle. The game then proceeds to meander through encounters with main-stay villains in the Spider-Man universe such as The Kingpin, Kraven, the Green Goblin and Carnage.
The game is an open world style game. The main missions are too short and the side missions are not very plentiful. Nearly all side missions are also in the first game, also most achievements are the same.
Like in the first game you can choose different Spider-Man outfits. Some costumes can be unlocked in the game, while others are featured as DLC.
One of the biggest changes compared to the first game is the web slinging. The first game had poor web slinging physics as Spider-Man would attach his webs onto the sky. Not to mention Spider-Man floated too much and it did not feel fast paced. In this game however, webs attach themselves to building this time and feels much faster. It’s a major improvement over past games, but still does not match the perfect web slinging physics from the 2004 Spider-Man 2 game.
The fighting mechanics in The Amazing Spider-Man 2 appear to have been simplified compared to the previous game. The previous game had a unique system that was similar to the fighting style from the Batman Arkham games. The combat just feels cheap and not as innovative as it was in the previous game which is a shame.
The graphics look outdated, they were even better in the first game.
The voice actors do only a passable job.
The Amazing Spider-Man 2 seems to be a lazy attempt to replicate the Batman: Arkham games with Spider-Man in the lead role. If you played the first Amazing Spider-Man game you can skip the second game, it is nearly the same but worse.

reviewText:
Spidey is tired, give him a break
This game is a hundred times better than the first Amazing Spider-Man game, but that's about it. TAS2 fixed a lot of the issues I had with the first game and added some interesting mechanics. Yet, the game feels rushed, uninspired and   tired.

To date I've played this game for about 27 hours and most of that time I've spent on swinging around NYC, which to this game's credit is the best part about it. Developer Beenox should not be blamed though, they have been making Spider-Man games for years with A VERY tight schedule. I don't think Beenox has any enthusiasm left in them to make Spidey games anymore. Much like Spider-Man, they need a well deserved break. On top of that, publisher Activision is known for rushing games to meet a certain deadline/maximize their profit and not caring about whether or not the is game ready for release. And nowhere is this more apparent than in TAS2.

This game would have needed a lot more development time to create a truly memorable Spidey game. Instead, we got a bland, rehash of the first game with nice additions and fixes, but this game just ended up being below average. I still like it personally though.

Pros
+ Swinging around in the open world are
+ Fighting crime (Even though it can get a bit tedious at times)
+ Collecting different Spidey costumes
+ Spider-Man himself
+ You can collect and read many real Spider-Man comics

Cons
- Uninteresting story
- Lackluster graphics (It's a next gen game)
- Boring boss fights
- The story has no focus whatsoever
- Bad optimization
- Tons of bugs and glitches

TL DR ;  The game is at it's best when you are swinging around New York. If you are looking for a superhero game with a strong story, buy Batman Arkham Asylum or Arkham City. If you are looking for a quick, fun, action filled superhero game, you might want to check this one out.

reviewText:
Alright, I am a die-hard Spidey fan, and i've played a decent amount of time. So here's what I realistically experienced:

Graphics: Well, the graphics are decent, nothing ''amazing'' about them, except for Spidey's character model which is cartoonish but nicely done (as well as the other available suits). You won't be impressed by anything else though, graphically speaking.

Audio: The quality of the sounds is impressive, it is very well done. The voice acting, the music, everything is very nice. Spidey's jokes are on point, and funny as always. What is dissapointing is the main menu music, which is just a elevator music type of sounds, very boring.

Story: Well, it's obvious this game was rushed, because the story is not at all polished and tied in. It's basically just a bunch of villains that are being thrown at you, and the theme of ''With great power comes great responsibility'' is heavily exploited. The Comic Book Stand and Stan Lee are a welcome breath of fresh air though. And the ending is, altough simple, kind of sweet and moralizing.

Gameplay: The Gameplay is practically taken from The Amazing Spiderman and tweaked. The Combat is similar, punch - dodge, evade system taken from the Batman series, but somehow it doesn't get boring that easily, i think because of the fact that when you hit someone it feels like you hit someone, the impact is felt. The Web-Swing mechanics are AWESOME, this is the best swinging game since the PS2 Spiderman 2 days. The Webs actually stick to buildings this time. There is an upgrading menu where you can upgrade Spiderman, and through the story you will unlock two Web-Based abilities which prove very useful. There are also Russian Hideouts which are EXTRAORDINARY, because they force you to think your next move, otherwise you will get caught and lose. Every hideout as well as other missions grant Spidey new unlockable suits which are looking SUPERB! All of them grant bonuses while wearing them, but some of them have rather useless bonuses (Spiderman 2099's bonuses are useless for example). The Boss Battles relay on patterns, and no boss will ever do something that you never expect (they all have around 2-3 type of attacks, so nothing hard at all). By the way, the main menu is pure garbage, looks like it was rushed in the last moments.

I will say this however: THE HERO OR MENACE SYSTEM IS UTTERLY GARBAGE. The side missions through the city are nice and all, and varied: car chase, petty theft, bomb defusing, civilian rescue, police deadlocks, etc. but the system is very rubbish. Each time you do a side mission you ''Heroic'' Level increases accordingly. BUT, if you ignore them too much, your ''Menace'' Level will increase to a point where the Task Force (The Elite Police) will start hunting you using several annoying methods. It wouldn't be such a rubbish system, but it all happens too fast. If you ignore just 10 minutes the sidequests while doing other things in the city (like collecting comic books) your Menace level will rise like crazy, which makes free roam almost IMPOSSIBLE. And on top of that, at the end of each side mission you witness a bland, stale Daily Bugle article which shows a picture of you and Whitney Chang presents the heroic act which you just did. A big minus from me !

Overall, if you are a fan you can ignore all these minuses, but if you don't have the nerve, avoid this game. I also recommend you buy it on sale (like i did) because it's not worth the full price.

First, I heard it was a short game, but it took me 20 hours to complete the main story because I was having so much fun in free roam, stopping crimes, leveling suits, and collecting the extras hidden around the city. If I rushed between story missions, it probably would have been short, but there are a crazy number of distractions along the way that I just couldn't help myself. Between the races, combat challenges, photo ops, and collectibles absolutely littered around the city, there are hours of gameplay.

I covered the entire city, stopping briefly to complete some Heroics to get the Taskforce off my back, and still I'm missing some audio tapes.

reviewText:
This is my favorite Spider-man game since Spider-man 2 (2004) and Ultimate Spider-man.
To start off with they've improved so much over what the first game struggled to accomplish.
That's not all though, it's a good game in it's own right.

Pros:

-Web swinging is much more fluid and it's fun. Webs stick to buildings again and you won't find your self cloud swinging anymore.
-Combat is much more responsive. It's still an Arkham clone as far as combat goes, but this time it's tackled leaps and bounds better than the first game.
-Stealth is much more fun to use along with spider-sense (another Arkham clone this time taking a detective visionesque approach)
-Upgrades are handled better and there is a section just for web travel.
-The camera is scaled back a bit and it makes it easier to manuever the city. It also makes the city seem larger, which was a huge problem in the first game to me, I felt like I was a giant sometimes in ASM1.
-Along with the camera Web Rush is much more intuitive and less floaty
-Humor. It feels like Spider-man with these wisecracks. Another major improvement over it's predecessors lackluster script.

Cons:

-Optimization is an issue yet again, but not as big of one as before. All I do is turn off motion blur, vsync, and take antialiasing down a little and I play on otherwise Ultra with 60fps using my AMD HD6850.
-Keyboard controls are kind of a mess. I can't imagine playing this without my 360 controller.
-Voice acting rarely matches the on screen mouth movements. I'm not expecting Pixar quality animation or anything, but come on.


Overall I give it an 8/10(negated in the edit). For $40 it's definitely worth it if you have any interest in the Spider-man franchise. With the release of this game it's actually given a place in my top five Spider-man games.
For comparison I gave Amazing Spider-man (2012) a 5/10.

Edit:
After nearly 100%ing this game I'll sadly be taking my review score down to a 6.5. It's still a good spidey game, but for the amount of content it offers, and the end game boss fights it's not as great as I held it. I still don't regret spending $40 on it, and I still recommend it over some other spider-man games.

reviewText:
The next entry in The Amazing Spider-Man game franchise from Beenox.

This game gets lot of things right than what Beenox were able to do on their last entry. Web swinging has been revamped and no longer feels dull and to easy to manage. You still miss a little momemtum, but you don't swing from the sky anymore 90-95% of the time. They also removed the weird option were you could just hold down the right trigger and just continue swinging without any consequense.

Added improvements to car chase, added fire situations and bomb threats to the city are present. It gets repetitive at times, but fires happens a different building at different time, so a little variation is present.

Dreadlocks returns and gets different location, under construction sites, hospitals or on rooftops. There you can choose wheather to be stealthy or head right on.

Combat stays the same, taking elements from the Arkham series, but still feels repetitive. They compensate this with new attacks like Seismic blast, Web-Pull and the improved Stealth. Those who enjoyed the combat last time will look forward to this.

Stealth takedowns have been improved. More variated animations and longer range. Reminds more of the stealth from Spider-Man Noir on Shattered Dimensions. Still, most times you end up with the same animation, so it is about where you are standing when taking him down. Stealth missions are alot harder, as enemies have a sight range when you trigger your spider-sense. A meter also present the awareness the guards have on you.

A few costumes from the last game returns, with the exception of Sam Raimi's red and blue, and black suit, Future Foundation, Negative, Cross Species and ASM black suit. New costumes are added instead, like 2099, Superior, Spider-Armor MKII and MKIII, Miles Morales, Ricochet, Hornet, Flipside, Electro Proof (PS3 or PS4 exclusive on pre-order) and a surprise costumes once you beat the game. Pre-order costumes available on all consoles except 3DS are Iron Spider, Classic Black Suit, Cosmic and Noir Spider-Man. The ultimate wardrobe, and most of them are unlockable by visiting russian hideout, where you take out all the guards silently and decipher Oscorp data.

Story is interesting, It begins with a flashback of Peter seeing his Uncle Ben shot by a mysterious murder. Two years after that he hunts for him and meets Herman Schultz before coming Shocker. He encounters Kraven, who teaches him the ways of hunting. Catches up with old friend Harry Osborn, and fight Wilson Fisk, The Kingpin. Cletus Kassady also makes an appereance, the rest you have to find out. The game includes elements from the film while being an own story taking place after Beenox last Amazing Spider-Man game. This time Beenox don't spoil anything from the movie, they only retell some facts that of course were spoiled on all the trailers from the new movie.

The are some bad thing that the game struggles with. Repetitive mission, some times a clumsy story. Bugs are present with stuttering, and lag who even occurs on high end hardware. The game do have much better graphics than last entry, but still isn't on the same lvl as the newer games like GTA V, Crysis 3, AC IV Black Flag and more. Bugs due to lightning, shadows, motion blur and more are a little present.

And the biggest dissapointment is the lack of possibility to use your unlocked costumes when entering a new game, like in the previous entry. Hope Beenox fixes this later with a patch or a code to unlock the costumes from the beginning.

Overall, this game stands a better chance than their last entry. It will grant you the possibility to really be Spider-Man in many ways and is definitely recommended for the veteran Spidey fans or for those who likes superhero videogames. The price is also cheap, on 29.99 euro.

Positives:
More side activities
Improved Web-Swinging
Better story
Many villains
Endless mode (always crimes in Manhattan)
New powers and attacks.

Negatives:
Still a little clumsy story
Repetitive combat
Little variation to the crimes
Bugs (they may be fixed later, we can hope)
Removed the option to keep unlocked costumes when entering a new game

reviewText:
Story: Welcome back friends to the second game in the Amazing Spiderman series. The story takes place after the first Amazing Spider Man game with much of the back story in place. That being said it wouldn't be a Spider-Man game without the mandatory Uncle Ben back story. This story follows much of the plot from the movie with some deviation. The story is rather short but overall not bad.

Appearance: The game plays fairly well. The city is rather beautiful and the web slinging is a lot of fun as normal. However the problems occur with the PC optimization. I may not have the highest end gaming rig but even on medium to high settings the game ran well for the most part but FPS dips happened and happened often. The worst was during the web slinging which I enjoyed the most.

Gameplay: The gameplay really hasn’t changed a heck of a lot over the course of the past few revisions. Go from point to point on a pretty standard city map by web slinging to achieve a given objective. It’s really that simple. Go to point A and perform the series of task, beat up a boss type, and swing off to the next objective. The story is fairly fleshed out but the gameplay is really repetitive.
What’s worse is that the side missions are really bland and bad. It’s the same missions over and over again. One would think you could just ignore the missions and enjoy the story but no. You must do missions constantly through the game to keep your public opinion in the positive. If it dips into the negative you will be faced with extra enemies and a greater struggle. This feature is poorly enacted and only serves to artificially increase the game play.

Achievements: The game, at this time, offers 46 achievements of which I have achieved 39. I occasionally fire up the game and work towards the last 7 achievements. Most of the achievements are easy, are story related, or are pretty fun to do. The last few I have require a bit of work and mostly grinding. The last few achievements are mostly because I have a fondness for working towards completing the game but honestly I wouldn’t be surprised if people didn’t want to dedicate too much time to getting all the achievements.

Bottom Line: This game is a pretty straight forward, pretty bland, and overall pretty standard Spider Man game. I got 15 hours of gameplay out of this and expect to have to put another five hours into the game before completion. I picked this up on a sale and if you really would like a spider man game this could do the job but I would not pay full price at all.

Worth the sale price of $10.  Don't bother with the previous game, though.  Skip straight to this one.

The previous game was bugged to the point where it was unplayable after just a couple missions.  It also had not-so-good textures on the Spidey suits.  The swinging wasn't as complicated, and the overall feel of the city wasn't quite as engrossing.

The Amazing Spider-Man 2 fixes what was wrong with the previous game in almost every way.  The Uncle Ben origin story is shown this time, though very briefly.  The characters have better textures.  There's less use of the movie counterpart's story material.  Granted, this game's story assumes you already know the characters from the first game in the series, but you can probably figure it out if you are a Spider-Man fan.  If you're not a fan, you probably will not care enough to get this game, anyway.

Overall, it's a great game to play on a controller, and if you're a fan of Spider-Man, it has a lot of iconic characters.  The combat is decent, perhaps a little repetitive and unchanged since the previous game, but the swinging is fun and the collectibles are actually kind of cool.  I wouldn't buy this at full price, but I was satisfied with the $10 purchase price, which included all the DLC.

reviewText:
This is a novelty game for Spiderman enthusiasts only! Otherwise get Spiderman 2 for the Xbox and PS2.

Good:
You get to save Stan Lee from a burning building at the start of the game.
The web swinging is good. You can only swing when there are buildings in range to swing from.
The map of Manhattan is pretty big so you never feel like you are boxed in by any invisible walls.

Disputable:
Combat is similar to that of the Arkham games, but reduced in quality. Spiderman can do everything ever really fast so this turns combat from perfectly timing all of your attacks and counters into button mashing the attack-button and then mashing counter-button when your spidersense goes off.

Stealth is also similar to the Arkham games. You have a spidersense view where you can see all the enemies and where they are looking then plan your attack. It's easier to just take people out by walking around the map than it is to do so as you would expect Spiderman would rappelling people from a ceiling.

There is a load of suits you can get so it's nice to customise your Spiderman but the way they give them to you is silly. Spiderman suits created by Oscorp and then stolen by the Russians which you then liberate as your own. This would work well for suit upgrades, but now actual suits.

Being a photographer for the Daily Bugle you can actively take pictures in the game whenever you want. You can't look back at pictures you have taken. And the only point where you do take pictures is to do appallingly bad detective work. There is not enough use of this feature to justify giving it a dedicated button mapping

Bad:
Playing as Peter Parker is the most boring part of the game by far, doing all the talking options in a conversation doesn't change how the game responds it just bores you with more cutscenes and often they will give you a general idea of everything when you close the conversation.

Spiderman has five lines that he says throughout the game.
If you are not doing the main objective then he will whine about it, even if you are doing a side quest.

There is a Hero/Menace bar which determines whether you get a buff in your abilities, but also if you become a menace then you get hunted by a police task force. It is not fun and is infact very tedious.

Mini games are as follows;
• stop a petty crime,
• rescue people from a burning building,
• save some woman from a car kidnapping,
• lift a small piece of rubble off of a civilian (including a man who has crawled under a train and got stuck),
• throw a bomb (which is always placed next to the same car in a parking lot) into the sea.

The mini games are shіtty and if you've played it once then you've played it a thousand times.
Don't forget that you have to repeatedly do these mini games to prevent yourself from becoming a menace because it is the only way you can get Hero points.

reviewText:
The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is not a great game, let's get that out of the way early, and after 2012s surprisingly ok ‘The amazing Spider-Man’ it is both a disappointment and a definite backwards step for the series.

The first major complaint that can be put against the game is that even on a high end PC the frame rate is constantly choppy, with visual screen tearing and seemingly random frame rate dips even when nothing to crazy is happening in game. The combat retains the style defined by 2009’s Batman Arkham Asylum but still doesn't manage to match its finesse and quality, making it no more complicated than wailing on a single button before dodging the odd attack and carrying on with the button mashing. I managed a 42 hit combo in the very first encounter of the game and as I'm not even particularly good at this type of action that's got to count for something.

The biggest grievance that can be had with the game however is its increased focus on what has always been the worst aspect of the series. The random side quests that require you to beat up some thugs, stop a shootout or rescue a hostage from a car have all returned. Rather than being optional like before, ignoring them adds to a karma style meter. Let it get too out of hand and special task force agents will actively hunt you across the city, stopping you from enjoying even the simple act of swinging around picking up collectables at your own pace for too long before you are forced back into more of the same side activities. Even when you finish the game there appears to be no way to switch this off meaning few will have the patience to see through collecting the 300 comics, multiple checkpoint races or many costumes.

On the subject of the swinging Beenox appear to have listened to fans of 2004s Spider-Man 2, with webs now requiring a building to stick to. Each of Spider-man’s arms is also controlled by the left and right triggers respectively and while not a terrible system in theory it leads to a lot of awkward situations in which you have very little control of the action while Spider-Man cycles one of a very short list of sarcastic quips about how webs need a building to stick to. It's almost as if he is mocking you for the control system fans asked for and how impractical it is to use.

It's not all bad though, the story while a bit slapdash is filled with a rogues gallery of villains from across the series and has some interesting moments and even some good twists. Collecting the suits is also still a draw and will bring out the inner comic book geek in almost anyone.

Overall the amazing Spider-Man 2 is a disappointing sequel, inferior to the first game in almost every way it smacks of something that had to be out in time for the release date of its theatrical counterpart and it's a shame. With a bit more time and a bit more thought I still think Spider-Man can have his Arkham Asylum moment.

reviewText:
Story:

The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is not based on the Movie entirely it has some story elements from the film and includes a lot of villains such as the Shocker, Kraven, Kingpin and many more but most of them have very little interaction with the story and just seem to be there for fanservice which i'm not complaining it was nice to see some of spidey's villains after a while, it felt kind of nostalgic but they don't add anything interesting to the story what so ever. By far the most interesting character is Stan Lee himself as he owns a comic book store in the game and it's just fun to interact with him instead of fighting the villains as they don't provide much of a challenge, other than Stan Spider-Man is done perfectly he has a great sense of humour and often mocks his enemies and will even comment on your web swinging if you fail to attatch to a building, though his jokes fall rather flat after hearing them multiple times.

Gameplay:

This is a open world web slinging adventure with Arkham City esque combat, along with a stealth mechanic from the first game which I found really enjoyable but this one I didn't enjoy as much, the combat itself is very simple it has one attack button, a counter button and a web button that's it, it doesn't have the large variety of options like in the Arkham games which this game is really trying to be it had the nerve to take the detective vision  via spider sense, even though it works well and you may as well keep it on just to see the enemies easier it makes the game look really ugly.

The stealth sections are fun you have at least more variety on how to take the enemies out particulary in the Russion Hideouts missions they are just the right length and at the end of it you can unlock a suit, which there are a lot of so I appreciate the suit variety as I recognize most of them from the comics, and they look really good too which is very faithful to the source material, the suits actually impact the combat as they have different bonuses like a faster healing rate, more damage, it's just a shame that the upgrade system doens't have as much variety which gives very little reason for replayablity, the only thing this game seems to do right is the web swinging which has improved from the first game and feels a bit closer to Spider-Man 2 most of the time webs stick to buildings, but in missions physics go out of the window and spidey is able to swing on nothing again come on Beenox this is 2014, games with physics like this shouldn't be allowed.

Another gripe I have with this game is that the frame rate is horrendous it's locked at 60 fps but most of the time you won't even hit that high, which means a lot of configuration in the settings to try and figure out what the hell the problem is. It's a pain to enter the settings too because Beenox decided to have the settings in a launcher now I don't mind that but when the game is constantly dropping frames, it means you have to exit the game and reboot it in order to change some settings it's frustrating, all this doesn't help that the game is fairly buggy often you will find enemies walking into walls when they don't see you, texture pop in during cutscenes which leads me to believe that this game was incredibly rushed as you could finish it in 4 hours, possibly more if you try to complete the side missions but even they're not always enjoyable to the extent you want to finish them all.

The reason why the side missions aren't always enjoyable is because of the new Hero/Menace feature it works like a reputation system where if you ignore crime you will get the blame and will be hunted down, if your a hero you will be praised and the Task Force which is Oscorp's police force will ignore you, this is understandable but when your a menace the Task Force which consist of flying enemies who constantly try and shoot you down is very annoying and this happens during main missions too which the game keeps reminding you to do, as it means ignoring the crime rate for a while dropping your morale to menace level meaning you have to repeat the same old side missions over again in order to regain your reputation, in which the side missions become a chore I've lost count on how many citizens i've saved from fire buildings, disposed bombs or beat up petty thugs as I just did it to raise my hero meter then ignored them most of the time, and the city has the most boring presentation of New York I have ever scene most of it is just window dressing as the villains don't interact with it neither can Spider-Man apart from web swinging which i'll admit is done very well here.

Graphics:

Now this is the fun part this game looks nothing like a current gen game even on PC with 16x AA can't save this game from looking blurry and low res especially the buildings, the texture on them is just awful as well as the character models which don't look that bad unless you take a closer look and you can see how out of date they are, there are a lot of texture pop-in as I mentioned earlier and you can see a lot of graphical glitches while swinging around the dull looking city, and it doesn't even perform that well either this is what happens when developers try to rush a game in order to be released with the movie you get a lot of problems that can be fixed with a patch, which I highly doubt Beenox will even to try to fix this game might perform better on consoles but other than that it's a very average looking game which is dissapointing because the first Amazing Spider-Man looked much better and performed better too.

Sound:

As for sound the voice acting in this is very cheesy some of the voices are good I liked such as Alli Hills who voiced Felicia Hardy/Black Cat who did a good a great job at portraying her character for little screen time we got, I liked Spider-Man's voice his dialogue is funny and I found myself chuckling from time to time at his quips sometimes I purposely missed the buildings just to hear one of his many jokes in the game, at least they got his personality right my favourite though has to be Stan Lee he intereacts with Peter Parker as sort of a father figure and it's great to hear some monolouges from the man himself.

The music is fairly standard nothing really stands out too much there's no electrifying soundtrack when fighting villains which is a shame because the movie had a good score and I was looking forward to the Electro fight but yeah nothing amazing about the soundtrack here.

Conclusion:

This is a passable open world marvel game and I can only see the most die hard Spider-Man fans like myself buying this game at full price which it's not worth it even for the costumes the pre-order bonus comes with, you can find some enjoyment from web swinging but the city is lifeless and i'm pretty sure New York isn't that boring so i'd give this a miss even unless it came at a really deep discount, which doesn't seem likely considering the game is published by Activision, save your money and you're better of playing the 1st Amazing Spider-Man at least until a better Spider-Man game comes out and does the web slinger justice however I believe they are on track with the web swinging, they just need to polish the graphics and gameplay elements then we might just have the spidey game we've all been waiting for since Spider-Man 2.

reviewText:
I am loving this game. Although, I'd pretty much only reccomend it as a Spidey fan.

I'll be honest when I say I wasn't exactly too optomistic about the game when it came out, but after playing it for a few minutes - I was instantly proven wrong! The game introduces a couple of new mechanics that I definitely would like to see kep in the game.

Pros:
-Many interesting villains to combat; all of who's boss battles, although being repetitive, are at least visually appealing enough to have you return
-Slightly improved combat system
-New web-swinging mechanics and improved web rush
-A for the most part interesting story
-A mainly decent voice cast
-Interesting Peter Parker segments
-Spidey quips that really tickled my ribs!
-Many refernces to comics; particularly the Ultimate Spider-Man comics
-A decent array of costumes (Note that the black suit isn't the 'true' black suit unfortunately)
-Soundtrack very similar to original film's OST
-New side missions and an unlimited supply too

Cons:
-Frame rate is capped at 30FPS if you keep Vsync on; be sure to disable this if you want smoother gameplay
-Short; I've finished the story in a day's worth (9 hrs) and the game is realtively easy too. I probably died only 3-4 times
-Story, although interesting, appears to become very rushed towards the end. Many plots appear to be poorly closed off and some just felt thrown in. Some moments are incredibly strong; notably around Kraven, Kingpin and Cletus Kasady but around the movie villains and tying everything together....it felt incomplete
-Whilst villains from the film are used (Shocker appears to have taken Rhino's place), important plot elements appear to have been thrown out entirely. The previous game heavily featured Gwen, this one only appears to reference her. A pity, as a battle with goblin in the clock tower could have made a VERY interesting boss battle.
-Glitches; there are quite a few. One or two that could require you to restart from the last checkpoint
-Awkward camera
-Although dynamic, some of the new side missions can get really repetitive
-(Personal Gripe) Some of the voices; namely Goblin's and Shocker's really don't seem to work for their characters. Also Carnage with no Venom to lead up to it? (It's okay if this was the last game of this series, but it likely isn't...) And using something closer to the current film's OST would've been cool too

All in all, I'm a HUGE spiey fan and I loved this game. If you're a big fan too, who doesn't mind some of these details, it's worth a try - maybe wait for a sale on it though.
A decent spidey game that makes good with what it has (Movie licenses). Just start an original game series now with some of the new features and the best from previous games, add a little more stuff to it and we could soon have a Spidey game to rival/exceed the Arkham games of batman! Soon.

What a disappointment.  The previous game, The Amazing Spiderman, was actually really fun.  Even though it was a console port, there was a lot of enjoyment to be had in the machanics of swinging and fighting.

reviewText:
Amazing Spider-Man 2 is a disgraceful attempt to cash in on the famous franchise by stealing ideas from the Arkham series which features Batman, it's a pitiful attempt to appeal to both fans of the comics and children unfimiliar with the comics but rather the movies.

The combat is like a clunky version of Batman Arkham Asylum/City/Origins. It controls horribly and often makes me wonder how it got past playtesting. It seems like Beenox have gotten tired of what Spider-Man games were and decided to cash in on a flawless system which wouldn't be too bad if they managed to get it right rather than make it feel like a cheap bootleg.

Controls are godawful and I found that the game would often be unable to recognise my mouse, a problem I've only had in this game. The button mappings cannot be remapped if I recall correctly making it very annoying to get used to the button mappings. Wallrunning is completely broken for me on KBM and makes it constantly switch to crawling and running when on a wall.

The Voice Work is absolutely horrible, the quality isn't too bad, but some of the things Spider-Man says isn't the witty dialogue or one liners we've come to expect from reading comics or watching older films, this game has about 10 lines and they repeat, constantly at an annoying rate.

The story is nothing to special, nothing as cool as Clone Saga (it was cool, just dragged on too long), or Clone Wars, or Back in Black or any of the Spider-Man stories that the comics are famous for. It's really generic and forgetable.

The one thing that the game that I liked was the inclusion of many costumes only seen in the comics and how you unlocked them as the game went on, and as a plus side, they included Scarlet Spider and the Symbiote Spider-Man.

There is no redeeming factors to this game unless you buy it at a bargain bin price cause 30 euros or the price I paid (€12.94) was not at all acceptable for the quality this game has.

I'm glad to have refunded the game and I do not want anyone else to fall into the same trap I fell into because they like the hero aswell.

This game seemed really cool and exciting from the videos, and I was happy about the fact that it was open world like the first Spiderman 2 Game. Honestly, it seems like this game was rushed out the door. The dialogue is terrible, not like cheesy comic book dialogue like you would expect, but dialogue like they're trying to appeal to an audience much younger than anyone who would play this game. The graphics were about as good as the graphics for the spiderman games that came out with the other spiderman movies. Those were amazing games for their time, but that was ten years ago. The FPS is really bad, and anytime you look around everything slows down and the screen goes blurry for a second. The rendering is very slow and only occurs when you're basically touching the building you are trying to see. Because of the FPS, the combat ends up consisting of a bunch of random clicks and hoping you can dodge in time, because the game is lagging so badly. The idea about having to use to different hands for web-swinging was really cool, but the Spiderman 2 game that came out in the early 2000's did a better job of the web-swinging mechanics as far as how you attach to buildings and nearby objects.

Altogether I would rate this game a 5/10, because they tried, I guess.
Had it been the early 2000's, and if they correctly optimized this game to PC it would be phenominal.
Since it's 2014 and compared to the caliber of games that have been coming out recently,
game that actually work and are fun to play, just don't buy this game unless you like being dissappointed.

The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is a fun distraction, albiet a very reptitive, clunky, and sort of boring one at that. The last AMS game was held up in regard towards it's open worlds design, but still lacked in overall varitey and actual letgitiamte fun web-slinging. The best thing about the ASM2 game is that the web-slinging is the best it's ever been in the series of Spider-man games, however everything else seems to be lacking a whole lot. For one the game not only copies Arkham's combat, but it's stealth predeator sections as well. At the very least the combat looks cool, but the stealth sections are a bit of a drag. Especially since the annoyting camera, doesn't at all help with the sneaking. If you get caught you can just as easily succumb the foes by disarming everyone. These are by far the worst part's of the game, since they drag on for too long and make me think about playing a better version of this like, the Arkharm series. In fact, the only thing I kept thinking about was how cool Arkham is and how utterly reptitive this game is. Now don't get me wrong. TASM2 has it's moments, but it's far an away from being a Spiderman game we should all jump out for. Now going to the last bit I did not like. The last three missions are basically the movie's villians and the video games main vilian back to back to back. Now usually having three bosses in a row, would be awesome, but since the bosses don't really require a change in tactics, it soon becomes one of the most reptitive hours in the entire game. The final boss reveal is awesome if somewhat dissapointing, that the game didn't just feature him as the main villian.
For People: Who love Spiderman! I mean really love Spiderman. I like Spiderman, but not enough to recommend this game to the average gamer.
Not For People: Who have anything less than a huge fandom for the web-head.
Now don't get me wrong the game has it's moments, and I personally enjoyed parts of it, but ultimately it's too reptitive and lifeless to recommend to people other than fans. This game is good, but it can be great or even amazing! It has the potential. Sony just has to let Beenox adequate time to make an amazing spiderman game and not just a slightly above average one.

reviewText:
Over the last decade and a half Spiderman games have ranged from simply amazing (Web of Shadows) to relatively good (PS1) to abyssmal (Spiderman 2 on PC). Many follow the same formula of open world free-roam play mixed with story elements, indoor areas, a large selection of alternate costumes you can wear in style and crimes in progress you can foil.     Ultimately the last point is the issue with TAS2.
While the majority of the game is great it is the random crimes that detract from the over all experience. In TAS2 many crimes will appear on the city map and you have a set amount of time to complete them before they vanish. These areas are cookie cutter encounters; repeated over and over with the same location, NPCs and objectives, and range from rescuing a car jacked woman to breaking a stand off between police and thugs. Failure to complete them removes Hero points and ultimately affects how the citizens of NYC view Spiderman and how they will react to him. Drop too low and the police will become hostile to you and attack you on sight, as will the Oscorp security forces dispatched to deal with the events in the game; including flying drones.
Being forced to complete these events becomes a monotonous chore after doing the same encounters over several dozen times and other than the Hero points, minor experience points and acheivements, does nothing to further the game or reward Spiderman in any significant way.
The major improvement over previous titles is the individual costumes you can upgrade along the way, each with its' own series of bonuses and they are very well done; both visually and the various bonuses they provide.

If you are a hardcore Spiderman fan and simply must play another free-roam Spidey game then by all means, pick this up. It is very fun (minus the random crimes) and the story is quite entertaining.

If you aren't a Spidey fan or simply don't want an experience where you must chew glass so you aren't attacked every 3 city blocks then I recommend you stay away from this title.

reviewText:
Friends... Gamers... Don't buy this game. Don't play it. Unless you can get it for FREE.

Clearly bound by budget/time constraints. Forced release along with the movie.
What really ticks me off the most about this game... and I don't know how they think it fair to charge full price for THIS... is the graphics. With sandbox games like GTAV and Infamous: 2nd son out there. WHAT is your excuse Beenox?? Please... I'm all ears. Anybody not wearing a mask has the face of something out of a PS2 game. Also mind boggling is that with this *AMAZINGLY* detailed environment they've created - I get frame dips to 40 when i turn the camera, regardless of high or low settings, on my i5, 16gb ram, GTX770 powered pc.
(Interesting factoid: 2nd son and this game are both limited to 30fps on console... This is understandable with 2nd son, but THIS game? Really??)

The ONLY thing this Spidey game has going for itself is the new web swing mechanic. It's realistic... it feels good. The combat this time around is a slightly better knock off of Arkham's combat system (the first game's combat was complete trash), but still not quite there. It's too easy and your opponents are almost always human so, Spidey face rolls them all. The side quests... don't get me started... repetitive garbage. I stopped playing before I reached a point where I could fairly judge the story, but i don't expect anything AMAZING there.

Sigh... I could go on guys, but i'm stopping there. This game is really a slap in the face to spidey fans, gamers and commerce. This is a problem with the entire gaming industry, but they are basically getting away with selling you a bottom of the range car for the same price as a high end luxury vehicle (Would you fall for that? I bought this included in the Amazing Spider-Man Franchise Bundle during the Summer Sale 76% off ($19.99), so I'm not gonna have too many complaints considering I didn't pay much for it. First off, this is better than the first game all around for one reason, and one reason only: It runs, and it runs without crashing at all (For me anyways). I played the entire game on the hardest difficulty (Super Hero) and beat it in 5 hours with no crash issues whatsoever. I wasn't expecting a massive story, but I'd say for sure I got my money's worth. What this game lacks that the first game did a better job in was the web-swinging mechanic; In the first game, you could just web-swing left and right like any other Spider-Man game has done, but with badass camera angles. In the second game though, the developers fell short: You can only web-swing if you're at some distance below buildings so if you're at an odd angle up in the air or below buildings, you're falling, my friend. Don't worry, though, there is no fall damage.

I won't spoil anything, but the game's story did put in some things that not only made no sense, but also spat in the face of the Spider-Man franchise as we know it today. I don't fault them for it, but I wish they would've done something that fit better to merge with The Amazing Spider-Man origin story. If you've seen the movies, keep in mind the games are supposed to take place after (somewhat during-ish for the second one) the movies, so don't think the games are perfect representations of the movies in video game form.

I do recommend this game completely for any average Spider-Man fan, but I cannot recommend it at full price. Buy it on sale, but dive in knowing you shouldn't take the game too seriously, and you'll enjoy it more. I hope my review cleared up any doubt or questioning as to whether or not you should buy it. It is worth a play in my opinion.

reviewText: The only good thing about this game is the web-swinging mechanics. That's about it. Everything else is just meh. Everything except for the Spider-Man suit looks like it was made by some 12-yr old who just came out of a 3D design class. They added a new Hero/Menace thing in the game which sounded interesting in the beginning but gets really annoying in the long run. If you don't attend to the city events your menace level increases and the Task Force starts bugging you and slowing you down. In order to balance the Hero/Menace meter you'd have to attend EVERY SINGLE crime scene, fire etc. and the frequency at which these city events take place would just ♥♥♥♥ you off and divert your focus from the main storyline events. And yeah, during the fires from which you have to save civilians you need to rely on your 'spider-sense' to track down the victims. Sounds fun but it is a PAIN IN THE BUTT.\n\nThis game had a lot of promising ideas but their execution is simply horrible and unsatisfying to say the least. This game is godawful. Horrible graphics that chug on my brand new rig, terribly awkward camera, laughably bad dialogue and motion capture (Spidey acts like a spaz in EVERY cutscene, waving his arms for no reason at all) and painfully boring missions. The only fun I had was the web swinging, but even that can't save this pitifully bad game. Don't waste your money like I did. Not worth $10, let alone $40.

The main problem this game has is the Hero/Menace system. It is completely broken even at best. To explain, there are side missions throughout the game that pop up frequently. They are boring, repetitive and tediously simple. If you do not complete these mission, they will expire after a few minutes and drop you down from a Hero to Menace. While you are a Menace, the city's Task Force will come after you, throwing up nets to block your progress and constant Hunter robot chase you. If that sounds really stupid, that's because it is.

It wouldn't be so bad if the missions were actually fun, but they aren't. Plus, you can't just roam around and collect comics like you could in the first game because if you neglect the side missions for even a few minutes, you'll end up a Menace and have no fun at all. This one simple mechanic kills the entire game, because it means you cannot roam around and webswing for fun without having tons of enemies and nets after you.

Until someone mods a fix into this, the game is literally unplayable unless you just beeline from one mission to the next. But in a Spider-Man game, who wants to do that?

I got this game because I thought it would be fun to sling around New York as the amazing spiderman. And this is basivcally all I've enjoyed so far.

The web slinging is fun and easy to use, for about 10 minutes, then theres only so many times you can enjoy swooping through the city. There are definitely some issuses with the swinging, when spidey swings too low he seems to have his body dragged across the ground, and going too close to a wall seems to cause an instant collision, which would be understandable but spidey seems to just start running directly up the building. I can unbderstand how this makes the game a bit easier to handle but I would have found a bit more of a realistic and challenging web slinging a bit more entertaining.

The graphics of the game seem a bit poor in my opinion. They arent ridiculous, but I'd place them at high end PS2 era, ESPECIALLY the cutscenes, with charatcers whos limbs look like a series of tubes. This is with the game running on the AMAZING settings, which i have seen through most of the reviews that alot of people are struggling to achieve, so i shudder to think what the rest of you are putting up with for the semi-enjoyable web slinging.

The fighting, as stated, is repetive and simple, smashing X (or square) untill all spideys foes are vanquised, occasionaly countering when your spidey senses tingle. Its nothing really too chalenging, and though seemingly fluid, characters will often snap to position when you enter a preset counter/special move. again, nothing wrong with this but when i know whats possible (i.e. batman arkham series) the fighting just seems to have been brushed over.

The game menus are poor to say the most. boring black background, white text, more or less just there to say YOU HAVE PAUSED THE GAME! Its not attractive, and its not tasteful. I would have though, seeing the pause menu is supposed to be peter checking out his phone, that surely the pause menu would have been a little mobile screen. This would have been alot more engaging and just seem less...again, PS2 era.

Other areas I would have like to have seen changed include spideys interactions withhis surroundungs. yes you punch a baddie near a waist high wall in a construction site and it explodes everywhere, but I want to see more. even just like a cracking of walls as spidey thropws his foes into them, some type of enviromental interactiopn would take the fights a long way, having spidey run up walls, thow people into them, bounce off them etc, this would all make the game much more engaging.

On the sma enote, I would have liked to be able to interact with the citizens of new york. I'm not saying I want to be able to throw a taxi at them, but just being able to pick up a taxi would be a start! reviewText:
Over the last decade and a half Spiderman games have ranged from simply amazing (Web of Shadows) to relatively good (PS1) to abyssmal (Spiderman 2 on PC). Many follow the same formula of open world free-roam play mixed with story elements, indoor areas, a large selection of alternate costumes you can wear in style and crimes in progress you can foil.     Ultimately the last point is the issue with TAS2.
While the majority of the game is great it is the random crimes that detract from the over all experience. In TAS2 many crimes will appear on the city map and you have a set amount of time to complete them before they vanish. These areas are cookie cutter encounters; repeated over and over with the same location, NPCs and objectives, and range from rescuing a car jacked woman to breaking a stand off between police and thugs. Failure to complete them removes Hero points and ultimately affects how the citizens of NYC view Spiderman and how they will react to him. Drop too low and the police will become hostile to you and attack you on sight, as will the Oscorp security forces dispatched to deal with the events in the game; including flying drones.
Being forced to complete these events becomes a monotonous chore after doing the same encounters over several dozen times and other than the Hero points, minor experience points and acheivements, does nothing to further the game or reward Spiderman in any significant way.
The major improvement over previous titles is the individual costumes you can upgrade along the way, each with its' own series of bonuses and they are very well done; both visually and the various bonuses they provide.

If you are a hardcore Spiderman fan and simply must play another free-roam Spidey game then by all means, pick this up. It is very fun (minus the random crimes) and the story is quite entertaining.

If you aren't a Spidey fan or simply don't want an experience where you must chew glass so you aren't attacked every 3 city blocks then I recommend you stay away from this title.

reviewText:
I must say that this game definitely deserves a lot more credit that what most of the critics out there have given it credit for.  As I am a fan of a lot of comic book heroes and villians, their comics, their stories, their superpowers, their weaknesses, their cartoons, their movies and their video games.  With that being said, I wouldn't simply put this game off.  I would however, consider purchasing this game when it is on sale between $20-$30 because this game could have been so much better than what it is, had Beenox taken a little more time to include longer missions and include either:  1). More of Spider-man's foes,  2). Longer running boss battles (instead of having you chase down petty crimes, car jackings, bomb disposal, ect.), or  3).  Incorporated a little extra detail into the game such as bricks, stones, glass and concrete shattering on impact during these fights, and 4).  Included those enormous Oscorp exterminating robots back!

I do enjoy the Hero/Menace system, but without having to swing across New York City for an hour or two just to level up to Hero Level 3, and then having it immediately drop back down to Hero, Level 2.  The visuals are also really good as well, there are quite a few of Spidey costumes to choose from, once you complete extra tasks to gain access to them.  And the villians' stories add a lot depth and substance into Spider-man's world/universe.  I really enjoyed how Peter Parker/Spider-man has both allies and enemies within most of these villians and how Peter Parker/Spider-man sympathizes with these enemies and doesn't kill them, but rather gives them a good whooping and attempts to teach his fallen enemies to see that there are other people out there who have things much worse [than the villian who Spider-man is fighting] and that they need to use their gifts to try to make things better within themselves and the world.

The storyline is short and sweet.  I could easily finished the game by now, but I like to try to collect all of the costumes and complete those sidequests just to max out Spider-man's suit's abilities.  Since Spider-man's suits level up by gaining Experince Points, the only way to make Spider-man as strong and resilient as possible is to collect as many suits as possible and level up whichever suit works best with your own individual play style. There have been quite a few epic boss battles, such as Electro, the Green Goblin, the Shocker......And I personally cannot wait to square-off against Carnage!

reviewText: This game is completely under rated. Even though its not the most original spiderman game ever made, to me it's up near the top of the list of my favorite Spider-man games. This game is basically a Spiderman 2 reskin with better combat and some pretty fun car chases. I'd probably give this game a 7/0. This game isnt nearly as bad as anyone says it is even though yes, the story is a little short and boss battles should have been better.
